faq.question: Where can I find more levels?

answer.p: Besides the 22 tested and cleaned up levels of the first island come with Pingus. There are also around 120 levels that might playable and another 100 levels that are incomplete at the moment. These levels can be found in the data/levels/playable data/levels/wip/ (wip = work in progress) directories:

dl.dd: The levels in playable/ directory might be playable, but is no guarantee for that. They might been broken due engine changes, they might be far too easy or far too or simply incomplete.

The wip/ directory levels that are not playable at all. Some of them even lack entrances and/or exits. Don't be surprised you can't play them. Instead, these levels can be used starting points for levels you want to create with the level editor.

faq.question: Pingus runs too slow. Is there any way to make it faster?

answer.p:
There are multiple ways to tune the running speed Pingus.
Firstly, reducing the screen depth (to 16bit, for example) on a slower computer give you a boost of around 50% percent, depending on hardware. X11 doesn't allow switching color depth at time, and the exact instructions for doing this are of the scope of this FAQ. Consult your documentation for more information.
Secondly, a gain in speed can be achieved reducing the display resolution of Pingus. For example, you want to run Pingus at 640x480 you can do this with following command:

Thirdly, you can run Pingus in a fast-mode. mode disables all costly particle effects and background. Thus, Pingus will look less pretty, but probably be a good amount faster. Fast-mode can be turned with:
Remember, the fast-mode has lots of room improvement. If it doesn't help you make Pingus run enough, not all is lost.

If that is not enough, you might also want to with the min-frame-skip and max-frame-skip options. Both should result in a more uniform frame-rate. This can make the game jerky, but playability can improved nonetheless.
Finally, the 'F11' key can help you a great deal your optimisation process by showing the frame-rate counter.
